column2: Oh, Ross, Mon, is it okay if I bring someone to your parent\xc2\x92s\nanniversary party?'
Yeah.'
Sure. Yeah.'
So, who\xc2\x92s the guy?'
Well, his name is Parker and I met him at the drycleaners.'
Oooh, did he put a little starch in your bloomers? (Sits up) Who said\nthat?'
Yeah, he\xc2\x92s really great though. He has this incredible zest for\nlife, and he treats me like a queen, except at night when he treats me like the naughty\ngirl I am.'
(To Ross) Oh, by the way. Would it be okay if I gave the toast to mom\nand dad this year?'
Uh, yeah, you sure you want to after what happened at their 20th?'
Yeah, I\xc2\x92d really like to.'
Okay, hopefully this time mom won\xc2\x92t boo you.'
Yes! Every year Ross makes the toast, and it\xc2\x92s always really\nmoving, and always makes them cry. Well this year I\xc2\x92m going to make them cry.'
And you wonder why Ross is their favorite?'

No! Really! Any time Ross makes a toast everyone cries, and hugs him,\nand pats him on the back and they all come up to me and say, "God, your\nbrother." Know what they\xc2\x92ll say this year? "God, you"'
Well I can promise you, at least one person will be crying. (Points to\nhimself) I\xc2\x92m an actor, and any actor worth himself can cry on cue. (snaps fingers)'
Really you can do that?'
Are you kidding me? Watch! (Makes funny faces trying to cry) Well I\ncan\xc2\x92t do it with you guys watching me!'
What are you doing?'
Oh I\xc2\x92m working on my toast for the party, or as I like to call it.\nSob fest 2002. Hey check this out. (Hands him a picture.)'
It\xc2\x92s a dog.'
It\xc2\x92s a dead dog. That\xc2\x92s Chi-Chi; she died when I was in high\nschool.'
It\xc2\x92s your parents\xc2\x92 anniversary and you\xc2\x92re going to talk\nabout their dead pet?'
The good stuff, huh?'
Hi!'
Hey!'
Hey!'
You got a present for my parents. That\xc2\x92s so sweet.'
Yeah, yeah, in honor of their 35th wedding anniversary, I had a\nstar named after them. '
Aww that is so cool.'
And I got them a book on Karma Sutra for the elderly.'
Hey, do you guys have any extra ribbon?'
Yeah, sure. What do you need? We got lace, satin, sateen, raffia,\ngingham, felt, (Pause) and I think my testacles may be in here too.'
(picking up Chi-Chi\xc2\x92s picture) Aww! Chi-Chi! Oh, I loved this dog!\nY\xc2\x92know Monica couldn\xc2\x92t get braces because Chi-Chi needed knee surgery.'
What?!'
You were the 200-pound 11-year-old who rode her!'
Hey!'
Hi!'
Everybody, this is Parker, Parker this is\xc2\x85'

No, no, no wait! Don\xc2\x92t tell me. Let me guess. (Points as he says\ntheir names) Joey, Monica, Ross, Rachel and, I\xc2\x92m sorry Phoebe didn\xc2\x92t mention\nyou. (Chandler makes a face) Chandler, I\xc2\x92m kidding all ready you\xc2\x92re my favorite!'
Ha!'
Why don\xc2\x92t all of you tell me a little about your self?'
Ah, actually, I\xc2\x92m sorry we-we probably should get going.'
(laughs) Classic Ross. Rachel, Rachel, oh how you glow. May I? (Puts\nhand on her stomach)'
I, uh, think you already are.'
Rachel, you have life growing inside you. Is there anything in this\nworld more miraculous than\xc2\x97Oh a picture of a dog! Whose is this?'
That\xc2\x92s my old dog. He passed away years ago.'
Oh well, at least you were lucky to have him. Bow-wow old friend,\nbow-wow. So where\xc2\x92s the party?'
It\xc2\x92s out on the island. It\xc2\x92s in Massapequa. '
Maaaassapequa, sounds like a magical place. Tell me about Massapequa, is\nit steep in Native American history? {Transcriber\xc2\x92s Note
Well, there is an Arby\xc2\x92s in the shape of a tee-pee.'
Okay, I got my note cards. (To Chandler) Do you got the presents? '
Yeah.'
And I\xc2\x92ve got the car keys.'
We\xc2\x92re driving!?'
Yeah.'
Aces!'
So uh, he seems like a nice guy.'
Yeah, yeah I like him a lot.'
Ya wanna hang back and take our own cab?'
Yeah, otherwise I\xc2\x92m not going.'
Hi'
Hi! (Kisses his mom.) Hey mom.'
This is such a great party! 35 years. Very impressive, do you guys have\nany pearls of wisdom? '
Jack?'
Why would you serve food on such a sharp stick? (Looking a\ntoothpick)'
That\xc2\x92s a good question, dad. That\xc2\x92s a good question\xc2\x85'
Hmmm\xc2\x85.'
(To Ross and Rachel) Congratulations you two!'
Thank you\xc2\x85we\xc2\x92re so excited'
And also, congratulations on your wedding.'
Wha\xc2\x97What?'

Can we talk to you for just a y\xc2\x92know\xc2\x85 It\xc2\x92s just a
little thing. Well we think it\xc2\x92s absolutely marvelous that you\xc2\x92re having this
baby out of wedlock, some of our friends are less open-minded. Which is why we\xc2\x92ve
told them all that you\xc2\x92re married.'
What?!'
Thanks for going along with this.'
Dad so what we have to pretend that we\xc2\x92re married?'
Son, I had to shave my ears for tonight. You can do this.'
Can you believe that?'
Yeah, if you\xc2\x92re going to do the ears, you might as well take a pass\nat the nosal area.'
No, us having to lie about being married.'

No, I know I don\xc2\x92t either, but ya know what, it\xc2\x92s their party,\nand it\xc2\x92s just one night. And we don\xc2\x92t even have to lie; we just won\xc2\x92t say\nanything. If it comes up again, we\xc2\x92ll just\xc2\x85smile. We\xc2\x92ll nod along.'
Ross!'
Rachel!'
Hi Aunt Lisa, Uncle Dan'
Congratulations on the baby, and on the wedding'
Hmmmm\xc2\x85.'
Here\xc2\x92s a little something to get you started. (Hands them a\ncheck)'
Oh\xc2\x85'
So, how\xc2\x92s married life treating you?'
(looking at the check) Unbelievable!'
We love marriage!'
Great!'
Hey'
Hey!'

What a beautiful place. What a great night! I have to tell you, being
here with all of you in Event Room C\xc2\x85I feel so lucky. I think of all the good times
that have happened here. The birthdays, the proms, the mitzvahs both bar and bat, but none
of them will compare with tonight! My God, I don\xc2\x92t want to forget this moment!
It\xc2\x92s like I want to take a mental picture of you all! Click! (He takes a mental
picture of them all.)'
I don\xc2\x92t think the flash went off.'
Dahaaa! (Punches Chandler in the arm and he makes a face of pain.)\nI\xc2\x92m going to find the men\xc2\x92s room, be right back.'
I\xc2\x92ll go with you'
Come on!'
Somewhere there is someone with a tranquilizer gun and a huge\nbutterfly net looking for that man.'
I have to go to the bathroom too, but I don\xc2\x92t want him complimenting\nmy thing.'
I\xc2\x92m so we weren\xc2\x92t in the car! Did he ever let up?'
He called the Long Island Expressway a concrete miracle.'

(imitating Parker) This room! This night! That waiter! His shoes! I must\ntake a mental picture! (He backs into someone.) Ooh sorry\xc2\x85(He looks behind him then\nnotices its Phoebe then stops his impression.)'
Were you guys making fun of Parker?'
That depends, how much did you hear?'
So, he a little enthusiastic, what\xc2\x92s wrong with that?'
It\xc2\x92s just that, it\xc2\x92s so much.'

Well, so what I like him! Do I make fun of the people you\xc2\x92ve dated?
Tag, Janice, Mona? No, because friends don\xc2\x92t do that. But, do you want my opinion? Do
you want it? \xc2\x91Cause in my opinion, your collective dating record reads like the
who\xc2\x92s who of human crap. (Walks off)'
I feel terrible.'
I know'
What was wrong with Mona?'
Open it! Open it! Open it!'
Yeah baby!'
So we never got to hear about your wedding!'
We were surprise that we weren\xc2\x92t invited.'
No, no, it was just our parents and 1 or 2 friends. It was a small\nwedding.'
But it was beautiful. I mean it was small, but kind of spectacular.'
Where did you have it?'
On a cliff, in Barbados, at sunset, and Stevie Wonder sang Isn\xc2\x92t\nShe Lovely as I walked down the aisle.'
Really? '
Yeah, Stevie\xc2\x92s an old family friend. (Hits Ross\xc2\x92s chest)'
Oh my God. That sounds amazing. I would love to see pictures.'
So would I. You wouldn\xc2\x92t think that Annie Liebawitz would forget to\nput film in the camera.'
Would you excuse us for a second? (Pulls Rachel off to the side)\nUmm\xc2\x85. what are you doing?'
What? I\xc2\x92m not you. This may be the only wedding I ever have. I want\nit to be amazing.'
Okay, okay. Ooooh, ooh maybe I rode in on a Harley. '
Okay, Ross, it has to be realistic.'
Are you okay? You seem kind of quiet.'
No, I\xc2\x92m fine. I\xc2\x92m great. I\xc2\x92m with you.'
And I\xc2\x92m with you! What a great time to be alive! Look at this\nplate-bouncy thing. (Bounces the plates) What an inspired solution to man\xc2\x92s plate\ndispensing problems. '
Hm huh, yeah.'
Ah! Oysters! Let me feed you one.'
No, that\xc2\x92s not necessary.'
Please.'
No, actually I don\xc2\x92t eat\xc2\x85'
I won\xc2\x92t quit until you try.'
Okay, fine! Fine! (Takes the oyster and pretends to eat it while\ndropping it on the floor) Mmm\xc2\x85hmmmmm\xc2\x85.'
What are they like? I\xc2\x92ve never had one.'
Why don\xc2\x92t you just try one?'
No, they look too weird.'
What are you doin\xc2\x92?'
Just going over my toast. Those two will never know what hit \xc2\x91em. I\ncan\xc2\x92t wait. They\xc2\x92re going to be crying so hard. They\xc2\x92re going to be\nfighting for breath. '
Ya know if you want to, I can just hold them down and you could\n(Punches the air).'
And my veil was lace, made by blind, Belgium nuns.'
Blind?'
Well, not at first, but it was very intricate work and they said even\nthough they lost their sight, it was all worth it.'
I\xc2\x92ll bet you looked beautiful\xc2\x85'
Well, I don\xc2\x92t know about that, but some said that I looked like a\nfloating angel.'
(To Ross) So, how did you propose?'
Oh yeah. That\xc2\x92s a great story.'
Well, um, actually, I-I took her to the planetarium.\nThat\xc2\x92s-that\xc2\x92s where we had our first date. Um, she walked in and I had the room\nfilled with lilies, her favorite flower\xc2\x85'
Oh that is so sweet!'
Shhh! I want to hear the rest!'

Then, Fred Astaire singing The Way You Look Tonight came on the\nsound system, and the lights came down. And I got down on one knee and written across the\ndome in the stars were the words "Will you marry me?"'
And the ring, was the size of my fist (makes a fist)!'
Yeah uh, Phoebe! Look umm, I want to apologize about before, okay? We were\nbeing jerks. Parker\xc2\x92s a nice guy and I\xc2\x92d like to get to know him.'
Then you better do it now.'
Why?'
Because I\xc2\x92m going to kill him'
What-what? '

You guys were right. He\xc2\x92s just too excited about\xc2\x85everything. I\nmean I\xc2\x92m all for living life, but this is the Geller\xc2\x92s 35th\nanniversary. Okay? Let\xc2\x92s call a spade a spade this party stinks.'
I know I\xc2\x92m having the worst time. There was a 15-minute line for the\nbuffet, and when I finally got up to the plates, I slipped on a giant booger!'
Are you sure it wasn\xc2\x92t an oyster?'
I guess it could\xc2\x92ve been, I didn\xc2\x92t really look at it.\nY\xc2\x92know, I just wiped it on Chandler\xc2\x92s coat and got the hell out of there.'
He\xc2\x92s just such a great guy I\xc2\x92m so excited about him.'
Oh hey, you should be excited about him. There\xc2\x92s nothing wrong with\nhim he\xc2\x92s a good guy. '
You think?'
Yeah. Ya know what I think; I think we were all just being too negative.'
You\xc2\x92re right. You\xc2\x92re right, he\xc2\x92s just embracing life. We\ncould all stand to be a little more like Parker. You know what? I am like him! I\xc2\x92m a\nsunny, positive person. '
Actually, you have a little bit of an edge.'
What\xc2\x92s that now?'
Nothing\xc2\x85'
Oh look it\xc2\x92s Parker! '
Look! It\xc2\x92s the bunny hop!'
Oooh I love it!'
You do?!'
Are you kidding? People acting like animals to music. Come on!'
Okay it\xc2\x92s time for the toast! Umm now-now, I know that Ross usually\ngives the toast, but this year I\xc2\x92m going to do it.'

No, no it\xc2\x92s going to be great. Really! Mom, Dad, when I got
married, one of the things that made me sure I could do it was the amazing example the two
of you set for me. For that and so many other things I want to say thank you. I know I
probably don\xc2\x92t say it enough, but I love you. (Pretends to cry hoping her parents
will join her.) When I look around this room, I\xc2\x92m-I\xc2\x92m saddened by the thought of
those who could not be here with us. Nana, my beloved grandmother who would so want to be
here, but she can\xc2\x92t because she\xc2\x92s dead. As is our dog Chi-Chi. I mean look how
cute she is. (Holds up the picture and pretends to cry again). Was. (To an old man by the
stage.) Do me a favor and pass this to my parents. Remember she\xc2\x92s dead. Okay, her and
Nana, gone. Wow! Hey does anybody remember when Debra Winger had to say goodbye to her
children in Terms of Endearment? (Chandler covers his ears) Didn\xc2\x92t see that?
No movie fans?! You want to hear something sad? The other day I was watching 60 Minutes
these orphans in Romania, who have been so neglected, they were incapable of love. (Waits
for people to cry, but doesn\xc2\x92t get any tears.) You people are made of stone!
Here\xc2\x92s to mom and dad! Whatever!'
Thank you Monica that was uh, interesting. Wasn\xc2\x92t it\ninteresting, Jack?'
(looking at the picture) Why don\xc2\x92t I remember this dog?'
Ross, why don\xc2\x92t you give us your toast now?'
Oh, no, Mom, it\xc2\x92s just Monica this year.'
You\xc2\x92re not going to say anything? On our 35th\nwedding anniversary'

No, of course, Um\xc2\x85 Um, everybody? Um, I-I just wanted to say\xc2\x85on
behalf of my new bride, Rachel (She turns around and smiles), and myself. Umm, that
if\xc2\x85if in 35 years, we\xc2\x92re half as happy as you guys are, we\xc2\x92ll count
ourselves the luckiest people in the world.'
(crying) Oh Ross\xc2\x85'
I just wish Nana were alive to hear Ross\xc2\x92s toast.'
My God what a fantastically well lit hallway!'
Can I get you something to drink? Like a water and Valium? '
I must say this apartment, its, its, There are no words\xc2\x85'
Oh thank God. '
It\xc2\x92s a haven. A third-floor paradise. A modern-day Eden in the\nmidst\xc2\x85'
Yeah? I know! I know! Uh huh? Listen why don\xc2\x92t we just um, sit and\nrelax? You know just be with each other. Quietly! '
That sounds great. (Sits down) My God this is the most comfortable couch\nI\xc2\x92ve ever sat on in my entire life. (Bounces on couch)'
Let\xc2\x92s try something else, let\xc2\x92s play a game.'
I love games!'
Shocking! Let\xc2\x92s play the game of who can stay quiet the longest.\n(Giggles)'
Or\xc2\x85Jenga.'
But, let\xc2\x92s play this one first. And remember whoever talks first\nloses! '
I lose, now Jenga.'
Oh my God! Oh my God! '
Is something wrong?'

Wrong? Really? You know the word wrong. Everything isn\xc2\x92t perfect?\nEverything isn\xc2\x92t magical? Everything isn\xc2\x92t a glow with the light of a million\nfairies? They were just brake lights, Parker! '
Well, excuse me for putting a good spin on a traffic jam!'
You don\xc2\x92t have to put a good spin on everything.'
I\xc2\x92m sorry that\xc2\x92s who I am. I\xc2\x92m a positive person.'
No! I am a positive person. You are like Santa Clause on Prozac, at Disneyland,\ngetting laid! '
So what do you want me to do, you want me to be more negative, less\nhappy?'
Much less happy!'
Fine! Well then to quote Ross, "I\xc2\x92d better be going." '
So long! Don\xc2\x92t let the best door in the world hit you in the ass on\nyour way out! (He exits and she slams the door behind him.)'
Isn\xc2\x92t this the most incredible fight you\xc2\x92ve ever had in your\nentire life? '
Uh huh. (Closes door)'
\xc2\x85and then, we could\xc2\x92ve gone from the ceremony to the reception\nwith you in the sidecar!'
Ross, it just wouldn\xc2\x92t have been feasible.'
But having a dove place the ring on your finger would\xc2\x92ve been no\nproblem?'
It was really fun being married to you tonight. '
Yeah! And! And, it was the easiest 400 bucks I\xc2\x92ve ever made.'
Okay Ross, can I uh, can I ask you something?'
Yeah.'
That proposal, at the planetarium\xc2\x85'
I know, I know it was stupid. '
Are you kidding?! With the, with the lilies, and-and the song, and the\nstars! It was\xc2\x85really wonderful! Did you just make that up? '
No, actually I thought about it when, when we were going out. It\xc2\x92s\nhow I imagined I uh, I would ask you to marry me. '
Well, that would\xc2\x92ve been very hard to say no too. '
It\xc2\x92s a good thing I didn\xc2\x92t do it, because it sounds like it\nwould\xc2\x92ve been a very expensive wedding. (Rachel laughs) Okay, good night'
Goodnight'
Even if the sidecar had a windscreen so your hair wouldn\xc2\x92t get messed\nup? '
I will think about it. '
That\xc2\x92s all I\xc2\x92m askin\xc2\x92 '
Okay that\xc2\x92s it. I give up. At mom and dad\xc2\x92s 40th\nanniversary, you\xc2\x92re the one giving the speech. '
Y\xc2\x92know I don\xc2\x92t understand why they didn\xc2\x92t cry. It was a\nbeautiful speech. '
Oh, come on. '

Hey! All that stuff you said about true love, you were right, I mean, we
did learn a lot from Mom and Dad! And that picture of Chi-Chi with her mischievous grin.
And what you said about Nana. Ohh, yeah she really would\xc2\x92ve wanted to be there. And
you know what? I think she was. '
(starts to cry) Oh good God, Ross! How the hell do you do it? '
